snippet: The hurricane, which meteorologists called the strongest recorded in the Western Hemisphere, toppled trees, triggered landslides and tore off roofs as it slammed into the coast.

byline.contributor: Elisabeth Malkin reported from Mexico City, and Azam Ahmed and Frances Robles from Miami. Paulina Villegas contributed reporting from Guadalajara, Mexico, and Liam Stack, Paula Duran and Katie Rogers from New York.
byline.original: By ELISABETH MALKIN, AZAM AHMED and FRANCES ROBLES

abstract: Hurricane Patricia hits Mexico, toppling trees, triggering landslides and tearing off roofs along country's Pacific Coast; many people are caught off guard as storm rapidly strengthened, making landfall as Category 5, with maximum sustained wind speeds of 165 miles per hour.
lead_paragraph: The hurricane, which meteorologists called the strongest recorded in the Western Hemisphere, toppled trees, triggered landslides and tore off roofs as it slammed into the coast.

headline.print_headline: Hurricane Slams Coast of Mexico With High Force
headline.main: Hurricane in Mexico Downgraded to Tropical Storm Patricia
